entry.pr: ˈär-inj, ˈär(-ə)nj; chiefly Northern & Midland ˈȯr-inj, ˈȯr(-ə)nj
entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French orrange, araunge, from Old Occitan auranja, from Arabic nāranj, from Persian nārang, from Sanskrit nāraṅga orange tree

def.dt: :a globose berry with a yellowish to reddish-orange rind and a sweet edible pulp
:any of various small evergreen citrus trees (genus Citrus) with glossy ovate leaves, hard yellow wood, fragrant white flowers, and fruits that are oranges
:any of several trees or fruits resembling the orange
:any of a group of colors that are between red and yellow in hue
:of, relating to, or sympathizing with Orangemen
city SW California N of Santa Ana pop 128,821
river 1300 miles (2092 kilometers) S Africa flowing from the Drakensberg in Lesotho W into the Atlantic
city SE France N of Avignon pop 27,999

entry.et: chromide, ultimately from Greek chromis, a sea fish

def.dt: :an Asian freshwater cichlid fish (Etroplus maculatus) that is orange or yellow with red spots and is often kept in tropical aquariums
:a European hawkweed (Hieracium aurantiacum) that has flower heads with bright orange-red rays and is a troublesome weed especially in northeastern North America
:a rough surface (as on porcelain) like that of an orange
:tea made from the smallest and youngest leaves of the shoot

entry.et: roughy the marine fish Arripis georgianus, short for tommy rough, from Tommy, given name + rough, probably alteration of ruff

def.dt: :a reddish-orange fish (Hoplostethus atlanticus) of deep subtropical and tropical waters that has firm white flesh and is caught commercially chiefly in the waters of New Zealand
